data.text: .@KGeorgieva : The third arrow of #Abenomics, structural reform, is essential for Japan. Labor market is a priority; female participation has increased— next, more training, career opportunities for women to excel.  https://t.co/3xDGMH3XEw https://t.co/wYNKc1kggG
IMF’s Jarvis: In discussions with the Jordanian authorities, we made good progress toward agreement on the broad objectives of a new IMF-supported program https://t.co/kVe3jnnu1G

eib: #MustRead➡️EIB Bank Lending #Survey for #CESEE shows optimistic opinion of the region, positive profitability & upbeat selective bias that make the regional strategy appealing to a majority of banking groups https://t.co/bwpTTJoszS #ViennaInitiative https://t.co/CYGKFiq95z

Tomorrow we reveal the cover and issue of our latest F&D magazine, which focuses on the economics of #climatechange. Be the first to learn the latest research and insight into how best we can solve the #climatecrisis by signing up to our F&D newsletter at https://t.co/mdxGXFhFJs https://t.co/v8udXVAaTu

#Japan’s recent economic performance has been solid, but in the medium-term its resilience will be tested by various global factors as well as by demographics. See this year’s Japan Article IV mission concluding statement. https://t.co/6es1989rRM https://t.co/FcHinpDUTa

Large migration flows from #Venezuela are expected to place immediate pressures on fiscal spending and labor markets in recipient economies, but over time they would also contribute to higher economic growth. Our latest #IMFBlog explains  https://t.co/oRAFqZA1i9 https://t.co/RKNuZmI1ht

Japan’s population is aging, and the labor force is shrinking at a rapid pace. Today, Managing Director @KGeorgieva visited a leading Japanese #automation-#robotics start-up and was impressed at how Japan is building greater resilience to face its #demographic challenges. https://t.co/DaLnljGAti

Low #interestrates make borrowing easier, but when rates rise, some countries could find it harder to service their debt. What can they do? #IMFBlog #ChartOfTheWeek https://t.co/m1ufoNDkGG https://t.co/NdVcuBygDI

The IMF has three main roles: economic policy advice, lending, and capacity development. How did we serve our 189 member countries in these areas? Find out in our latest Annual Report. https://t.co/oIQfbLUPTu https://t.co/qXJteiVgPV

The world's latest humanitarian crisis is unfolding in #LatAm, where about 4.6 million Venezuelan migrants are fleeing harsh economic and living conditions. #IMFBlog looks at the impact on neighboring economies https://t.co/oRAFqZA1i9 #Venezuela https://t.co/PkW1dW7YPK

Deputy Managing Director Tao Zhang visiting wind farm in #Serbia w/ energy minister Aleksandar Antic. Wind has emerged as a power source that can help reduce carbon emissions substantially and mitigate the effects of global warming. https://t.co/fU4yPaJraJ

Without a clear end in sight to the crisis in #Venezuela, how can #LatAm governments both serve the humanitarian needs of refugees while protecting their citizens and economies? https://t.co/oRAFqZA1i9 https://t.co/fV7e7TyfpK

IMF’s Zhang and @SerbianPM Ana Brnabic took stock of the country’s robust economic performance. The IMF stands ready to continue the successful collaboration with Serbia in helping to achieve stronger growth and to improve living standards of all. https://t.co/PTLgM2Ruo1

IMF analysis shows countries lose about 30% of potential returns on their investment in #infrastructure. This means instead of building a 10km road, only 7km gets completed w/ money spent. Countries can have better infrastructure if they improve the quality of their investments. https://t.co/moFJkbkBuo
.@KGeorgieva: Development takes time and is not instant. So my plea is: stay the course to create a better investment climate in Africa. #CompactwithAfrica https://t.co/ltwXWn4ZzA

How can we spur private sector investment & job creation in Africa?
✔️ Get the word out that #CompactwithAfrica countries offer safe investment opportunities
✔️Development partners must provide fine-tuned public support so Compact countries can benefit from low interest rates https://t.co/OKS1jFk5cB
Yesterday, @KGeorgieva participated in the #CompactwithAfrica conference and took stock of where we stand now, 2 years after the launch of this initiative. Watch the video ⬇️ https://t.co/uAIXUVkVUz

In a new video, @CNBCi goes behind-the-scenes at the IMF to explain the process and the intense work that goes into putting together economic predictions and analysis for the World Economic Outlook report #WEO.   https://t.co/Sbx0AqxmuW

Should central bank digital currencies accrue interest? Should they be anonymous like cash? What are the potential trade-offs? A new IMF working paper assesses the welfare benefits and risks. https://t.co/lo6ibNWNKH #Fintech https://t.co/XgWI8c07kx
#SocialProtection floors give #workers something to walk on. Listen to @ilo Deputy DG for policy in the latest @imf_podcast https://t.co/InVqu6Wfdr

IMF’s Deputy Managing Director Zhang met with North Macedonia FM @nina_angelovska and governor Anita Angelovska Bezhoska of @narodna_banka in Skopje. Important governance and fiscal reforms have helped the economy to reach solid growth. Essential to stay on the path of reforms. https://t.co/nObRcOTbER

Overcoming infrastructure bottlenecks—poor roads, unreliable energy networks & below standard schools— is a top priority to achieve sustainable economic growth and development. Watch how the IMF supports its member countries to better manage their infrastructure investment. https://t.co/QQ1SzlC61R

IMF analysis shows countries lose about 3️⃣0️⃣% of potential returns on public investment due to weak infrastructure governance. Countries can close 2/3 of the efficiency gap by building stronger institutions & frameworks to spend on #infrastructure https://t.co/HgJXIzh2vh https://t.co/0v582IAWFP

Exploring Kosovo Digital School. Deputy Managing Director Zhang visiting fascinating venue for kids and teens, that helps to develop their digital skills and opens the world of coding - the language of the future. https://t.co/66GNR84XUM

The best way to reduce carbon emissions and limit global warming is to put a price of $75 per ton on them. Paying for emissions lets people decide how best to reduce energy use and switch to cleaner energy. Learn more, download the #FiscalMonitor ➡️ https://t.co/zm6K4DN18u https://t.co/wNlnuIIfzj
